forecast.no_outcome_scenario: At least one of the remaining escapees successfully evades capture through July 1 by leaving the area, having external support, or finding effective hiding locations. As time passes, trails grow cold and the most resourceful escapee(s) continue to avoid law enforcement.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Intensive law enforcement efforts, including potential federal assistance, public tips, and coordinated searches, result in the rapid recapture of all remaining escapees within the next 32 days. The escapees make mistakes, are recognized by the public, or are turned in by associates.
forecast.rationale: According to the report from May 19 (3 days post-escape), 3 of the 10 escapees had been recaptured, leaving 7 at large. With 14 days having passed since the escape and no updated information available, the status quo suggests several escapees likely remain free. Historical patterns show that recapture rates decline sharply after the initial days - the easiest targets are caught first, while those who evade capture longer tend to be more resourceful or have better support networks. The question structure heavily favors a No outcome since ALL 10 must be recaptured for Yes, while just ONE remaining free results in No. With approximately 32 days remaining and potentially 5-7 escapees still at large (assuming 1-2 more captured since May 19), the probability of complete recapture is constrained. Law enforcement resources may be stretched, some escapees may have left Louisiana entirely, and the longer timeline allows for more evasion opportunities. My forecast would be higher if: (1) I had evidence of additional recent captures, (2) there were reports of intensive federal involvement, or (3) the timeframe were longer. It would be lower if I had evidence that sophisticated or violent offenders were among those still at large, or if any had definitely left the state.
